title: NAB slashes hundreds of roles, moves jobs overseas
text:
NAB has joined a growing list of major Australian banks cutting back on staff, confirming this morning that it has slashed 410 roles.

The bank confirmed it has shed hundreds of jobs in its technology and enterprise operations division as part of a mass redundancy plan.

Impacted staff were informed of the cuts yesterday and some will be transitioned to new roles.

NAB will cut hundreds of jobs and move some roles overseas. (Reuters)

"Like many businesses, we regularly look at the way we work and how we're structured to deliver the best experience we can for our customers," a spokesperson for NAB said.

"The environment we operate in is constantly changing and we need to have the right structures alongside the right skills and capabilities in the right locations to help us deliver for our customers.

"These decisions are always difficult and we understand the impact they can have on our colleagues."

NAB said it will look into redeployment and career transition options for the team members who have been made redundant.

Some roles may also move to different geographic locations.

It has been reported that new roles have been created in India and Vietnam.

READ MORE: Swedish health minister collapses during media conference

NAB said it will look into redeployment and career transition options for impacted staff. (Ben Rushton/Fairfax Media)

"While some roles are no longer required or may move location, we are also creating new roles across all locations as necessary, to ensure we are set up for success and can deliver better outcomes," the NAB spokesperson added.

"Having a global workforce is helping us generate better outcomes for customers in a number of ways, leveraging global time zones to extend our hours of operation, speeding up processes and improving turnaround times for our customers."

NAB is headquartered in Docklands, Melbourne.

All of Australia's big four banks have taken drastic redundancy measures in recent months.

Just yesterday ANZ announced it would slash thousands of jobs from its Melbourne offices.

It is believed the majority of 3500 full-time roles and 1000 contractor jobs cut from the bank will impact staff at ANZ's office in Docklands, Melbourne.

In May, it was reported Westpac was planning to shed more than 1500 positions in a bid to streamline systems.

Commonwealth Bank cut 164 jobs from its technology division in March.

title: Marijuana may cause chromosomal defects in human egg cells, study finds
text:
Marijuana may damage oocytes — unfertilised eggs in female ovaries — in ways researchers worry may lead to infertility, miscarriage and possible genetic defects in babies , new research has found.

Higher levels of tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC — a chemical in marijuana that produces a euphoric feeling or "high" — was linked with changes in how eggs mature and a possible increase in chromosome malformations, according to the study published in the journal Nature Communications.

"The findings of this study are concerning and highlight the importance of a cautious approach in using cannabis when planning to conceive," obstetrician Dr Jamie Lo, an associate professor of obstetrics, gynaecology and urology in the School of Medicine at Oregon Health & Science University in Portland, said in an email. She was not involved with the study.

Believing marijuana to be safe, an increasing number of women turn to weed to handle nausea and other pregnancy complications, experts say. (juanmahache/Moment RF/Getty Images)

Use of marijuana during pregnancy is rising.

A June study found past-month self-reported cannabis use has more than tripled among pregnant women in the US from 2002 to 2020.

Numerous studies have linked marijuana use during pregnancy to autism, poor fetal development, low infant birth weight, dangerously early deliveries and even death.

The new study is "an exciting and novel approach to address a key gap in knowledge," Lo, who studies marijuana and fertility, said.

A number of studies have looked at how marijuana might affect sperm, but until now no study had looked at the impact of marijuana on the human egg and ovarian follicle, she said.

A follicle is a small, fluid-filled sac in the ovary that contains one unfertilised egg.

During a woman's menstrual cycle, hormones kick off a chain of events that help the oocyte segregate chromosomes so it will be ready for fertilisation by sperm.

Higher levels of THC appeared to impact this process, said lead study author Cyntia Duval, who conducted the study while a postdoctoral research fellow in ovarian biology at the University of Toronto.

However, the study can only show an association and not a direct cause and effect, said Duval, who now directs applied research at CReATe Fertility Centre, a fertility clinic in Toronto, Canada.

CReATe stands for Canadian Reproductive Assisted Technology.

"This is a hypothesis, and the worst thing I would want is for the public to read this and become fearful," she said.

"More studies are needed to verify our findings and determine how or even if the changes we observed affect reproduction."

Higher levels of THC most harmful

Researchers analysed over 1000 ovarian fluid samples from patients undergoing infertility treatment.

Oocytes from a smaller group of 62 patients who tested positive for THC were compared with a matched control group with no detectable use of cannabis.

Compared with the control group, the group of patients with detectable levels of THC was associated with an increased oocyte maturation rate and a lower number of embryos with the correct number of chromosomes, the study team found.

On first glance, a higher maturation rate may appear to be positive, but developing too quickly can create problems with how oocytes prepare for reproduction, Duval said.

"Chromosomes need time to align perfectly to be ready to be fertilised by sperm and create healthy embryos," she said.

"So yes, we have more oocytes that are mature, but at what price if they don't have the right number of chromosomes?"

READ MORE: Swedish health minister collapses during media conference

Marijuana is becoming legal in more parts of the world, seeing its use increase. (AP)

Another part of the study examined extremely immature oocytes in vitro, which means in a test tube in the lab.

The oocytes were donated by women undergoing fertility treatment and were not suitable for use, Duval said.

When exposed to THC for 24 hours in a petri dish, immature oocytes receiving higher levels of THC had more altered spindles — the structures that help chromosomes to segregate properly — which can lead to failures in embryonic development.

"The finding that exposure to higher levels of THC could be associated with worsened fertility and increased reproductive complications may help patients that cannot abstain from cannabis with a harm-reduction strategy," Lo said.

"With this information, these patients can consider reducing the amount of cannabis that they are using to mitigate adverse outcomes to their babies."

The potency of THC is not always obvious

The potency of THC quadrupled between 1995 and 2022 and is now even higher, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

"Cannabis flower and concentrates in dispensaries can have THC concentrations of more than 40 per cent.

Higher THC concentrations have been associated with a greater likelihood of cannabis use progressing to cannabis use disorder, among other health concerns," the Institute states on its website.

This dangerous rise in potency may not be clear to consumers, experts fear. Looking at a product label might tell a person the "precise potency" of THC in a store where marijuana is legally sold.

But "people buying cannabis illegally may not be able to access reliable information about the potency of the product they are using," researcher Tom Freeman, a professor of psychology at the University of Bath, told CNN in a prior interview.

He was not involved in the study.

The group of patients with detectable levels of THC was associated with an increased oocyte maturation rate and a lower number of embryos with the correct number of chromosomes (Getty)

"However, certain types of cannabis are typically more potent than others — cannabis extracts are typically more potent than cannabis flower," Freeman, director of the Addiction and Mental Health Group at the university in the United Kingdom, said.

While people do try to adjust their consumption when the potency of their cannabis varies, "such as by adding less cannabis to their joint or inhaling less deeply," these efforts fail to completely work, he added.

That means "higher potency products still deliver a larger dose of THC to consumers than lower potency products," Freeman said.

Women may unknowingly harm the success of their future pregnancy by being exposed to higher THC levels than they intended, Lo said.

"Because it's hard to know the specific level of THC in various cannabis products on the shelves, I advise my patients to consider safer alternatives to treat the symptoms they're using cannabis for or at least try to reduce the frequency of their use."

title: Confusion after New Zealand council asphalts a road cone into the footpath
text:
Is it art? An "epic fail?" Or a roadworks accident?

A photo of a road cone asphalted into a New Zealand footpath in New Plymouth, on the west coast of the North Island, has drawn derision on a Facebook community page, with one comment describing it as an "epic fail".

"OMG surely someone taking the piss," wrote another poster.

Yes, it's a road cone asphalted into the footpath, deliberately, by the council. (Stuff)

"Some drunk person is gonna try to kick that," said another.

Yet another suggested it could be art that becomes a local landmark.

Melanie, who posted the photo, said she used the road daily.

She found the "bizarre" and she wasn't alone - screenshots of the post are doing the rounds on social media.

However, a New Plymouth District Council spokesperson said the cone was simply protecting an exposed pipe.

The pipe connects a water main to an adjacent house, and was left uncovered while crews installed a new main, he said.

A temporary asphalt patch was laid over the path as a safety measure, securing the cone in place over the pipe. Later this year, the connection will be finished and a permanent surface put down.

The council had not fielded any complaints over the cone, the spokesperson said.

Road cones have been in the spotlight this year, with the Government announcing a crackdown on their use.

Prime Minister Christopher Luxon said there were "hundreds of them doing very, very little", and his deputy, David Seymour, complained about too many "frickin' cones".

Even Transport Minister Chris Bishop calls their deployment "overzealous".

To tackle the tide of road cones, the Government launched a hotline for concerns about their use earlier this year. RNZ reported 650 reports in the hotline's first month of use. In Wellington, there were 115 complaints in two months.

title: Swedish health minister collapses during media conference
text:
A media conference in Sweden was abruptly brought to a halt after the country's newly appointed Health Minister collapsed.

Elisabet Lann was standing next to the country's Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson and other officials when she suddenly fell over and hit her head on Tuesday.

Video footage shows Kristersson and other people on the stage in Stockholm rushing to help her as she tumbled over.

Sweden's Health Minister Elizabet Lann collapsed during a media conference. (Nine)

Lann was given first aid while an ambulance was called, local media reports.

She returned a short time later with no apparent injuries, saying her collapse was sparked by a blood sugar drop.

﻿A government statement said her life was out of danger and her health was stable.

Lann had been appointed health minister on Monday after the sudden resignation of her predecessor.

title: Aussies like Casper are working younger as the cost-of-living crisis rages on
text:
EXCLUSIVE: If you've caught yourself thinking the staff at your local Coles or Woolworths look particularly young these days, it's not just your imagination.

Australians are joining the workforce younger than ever, largely in response to the ongoing cost of living crisis.

New research from Employment Hero revealed that jobs among Aussies aged 14 to 17 surged by 30 per cent in the past year.

READ MORE: ﻿ Apple unveils thinnest iPhone ever as new changes revealed

Casper Huisken, 17, has started working at his local supermarket. (Supplied)

Jobs among 18 to 24-year-olds also jumped by more than 16 per cent, signalling a prominent generational shift as young Aussies try to get ahead financially.

﻿Casper Huisken, 17, is juggling a job at his local supermarket with his Year 12 studied in the hopes of building a financial safety net before he even finishes high school.

"I wanted to earn money earlier because it gets expensive [when you're] outside of school," he told 9news.com.au.

"It just feels good to have some money to rely on."

Working a few shifts a week also forces him to manage his time carefully around homework and assignments, which he said has helped him focus.

But he worries that it will be hard to keep up with the rising cost of living – even with a head start.

The top 10 jobs actually making money in cost-of-living crisis View Gallery

Employment Hero's inaugural Annual Jobs Report found that Gen Z Aussies are entering the workforce in record numbers as the cost of living crisis continues.

More than half of those aged 18 to 24 also work more than one job.

By comparison, only 20 per cent of workers over the age of 55﻿ hold multiple jobs and only one in three across the total working population.

"Teenagers are clocking shifts to save for a future they know is going to be expensive," Employment Hero chief executive Ben Thompson said.

Meanwhile, Millennials are most likely to use tools like Earned Wage Access (EWA) to withdraw cash before payday to foot everyday bills.

And the majority of Aussies are prioritising job stability over all else, especially young workers.

Cyber safety specialist Annabelle, 24, is among them.

"In the industry that I work in, which is tech, there's a lot of layoffs and they can happen quite suddenly," she told 9news.com.au.

"Everything's changing a lot so over the past few years, I've definitely valued job security."

READ MORE: ﻿ The chicken who lived 18 months without a head

Annabelle, 24, is a cyber safety specialist and has been working since she was 14. (Supplied)

Annabelle got her first job at 14 and worked multiple jobs all through high school and uni, hoping to set herself up for the future.

But she couldn't have planned for the COVID-19 pandemic or cost of living crisis.

Now she's considering picking up a second job on top of her full-time role to help cover essentials like rent and groceries while she tries to keep saving for life's big moments.

Because if she doesn't put money away for a wedding, a house, and kids now, she might never afford them.﻿

﻿"I'd like to have a house and be comfortable, and also have the financial freedom if I want to travel to travel," she said.

"But it's hard ... you can't really do everything, you definitely have to prioritize what you what you want most."

Annabelle is grateful her family encouraged her to develop financial skills from a young age.

About ﻿8.5 million Aussie adults are considered financially illiterate according to 2020 stats, and only 28 per cent of teen boys and 15 per cent of teen girls demonstrate basic financial skills.

READ MORE: ﻿ Prince Harry returns to UK amid reunion speculation

Thankfully, a growing number of young people are ﻿starting work and saving young in the hopes of getting ahead of the curve.

Huisken plans to keep working through his final year of school and build up a little nest egg to see him through to his next chapter.

﻿Many of his friends are starting work and saving up too.

"It seems like a great thing to get into early," he said.

"﻿Because [the cost of licing] already is quite expensive, and if it keeps getting more expensive, then that would be very bad for us."

title: US 'superstar' to headline NRL, NRLW grand final entertainment
text:
Grammy-nominated chart topper Teddy Swims will headline this year's entertainment for the NRL and NRLW Grand Final Day, it has been announced.

US singer Swims, well-known and acclaimed for his I've Tried Everything But Therapy albums﻿ and hit single Lose Control, was announced as the main act for the entertainment roster at Accor Stadium on Sunday, October 5.

The performance will also kick off his tour of Australia and New Zealand.

Teddy Swims onstage. (Getty)

﻿NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo said Swims was one of the most exciting musicians in the world.

"Grand Final day is a special event on the sporting calendar, capturing moments that last forever," he said.

"Including a fresh superstar like Teddy Swims alongside some of the best male and female athletes in the world will take the entertainment experience for sports fans to a whole new level."

Swims will tour Australia following the performance. (Getty)

Swims said he was "so excited" to be scheduled to play.

"Australia has always been a second home to me," he said.

"Every time I am there I am overwhelmed by how welcoming the people are, I fall more in love with the culture, and just everything about it.

"So, to be welcomed to perform one of the biggest nights in Australia is a huge honour."

title: For Penrith's dynasty to survive it must destroy one of its favourite sons
text:
Penrith's premiership dynasty has many fathers, but if it's to continue it will have to strike one of them down when it takes on James Fisher-Harris and the Warriors on Saturday night.

As wounded as the Kiwi club may be after an indifferent run into the finals, Fisher-Harris is sure to have them breathing fire in front of a frenzied Auckland crowd as both sides' seasons go on the line.

Fisher-Harris's ruthlessness as a competitor, his relentless intensity, his utter lack of mercy, and his ongoing refusal to consider the concepts of fatigue or pain are all important parts of the foundations on which the Panthers built their greatness.

Fisher-Harris led from the front for each of Penrith's four premiership wins. (Getty Images: Mark Kolbe)

Now those same qualities are fixed on Penrith's demise in a high-stakes match for the first time, and one of the creators of the greatest winning run of modern times is aiming to destroy what he helped forge.

So Penrith know exactly what to expect, and it's not so much they'll leave their history with Fisher-Harris on the Mt Smart Stadium sideline, even if a knockout semifinal is hardly the time to get sentimental.

They'll take the memories out there with them and show the Kiwi prop the respect he demands, the only way they know how.

Fisher-Harris is one of the most decorated players of Penrith's dynasty. (Getty Images: Matt Blyth )

"I'll definitely go at him. Fish knows I love the challenge, but I always give respect to my uncle, I can't wait to go up against him," said winger Brian To'o.

"You always fight with your brothers; it brings the best out of you.

"It goes both ways, we want to bring the best out of each other, and that only happens when you go 110 per cent at each other.

"It's always been like that, everyone who's here and everyone who's left knows the go."

That means Fisher-Harris is certain to respond in kind. He still doesn't say much, but this is a serious business, and he never wants to play teams who muck around.

Fisher-Harris is the kind of player who forgot how to take a backward step so long ago it might be more accurate to say he never learned.

His journey to Penrith over a decade ago is the stuff of legend. Raised in the town of Kohukohu in New Zealand — which has a population of about 300 — Fisher-Harris was playing first-grade rugby alongside his father at 15.

When he first came to Sydney, he packed one bag. He didn't know how to catch a train or a bus and lived in apartments above a horse stable.

Fisher-Harris helped drive much of Penrith's success over the past four seasons. (Getty Images: Brendon Thorne)

He was one of the first of the future Penrith legends to come through the grades — Isaah Yeo is the only one of the homegrown Panthers who debuted before him, and the two of them are the only players of their generation to play more than 200 games for the club.

By the time To'o was rising through the ranks, Fisher-Harris was already a focal point for the side, even if they and he were far from what they would become.

Fisher-Harris' status as an elite prop predates the premierships — his first truly great season came in 2019, the same year To'o debuted, but he'd been someone for the blockbusting winger to look to well before that.

"I was still in Under 20s, he was training in grade. He came up to me, shook my hand, asked me how training and everything was going," To'o said.

"It was a lot of words for him to say at once. He was very softly spoken then, but his actions spoke for themselves.

"He's been a role model figure for me, I always appreciated that, and I'll never forget it."

Cleary and Luai set for first meeting as NRL foes Photo shows Two men celebrate with the NRL premiership trophy Nathan Cleary and Jarome Luai drove Penrith to unfathomable heights together but now the two will face off in the NRL for the first time with both their seasons at a crossroads.

Now, the Panthers are filled with players who came up under the high standards Fisher-Harris helped inspire, and Lindsay Smith, who replaced him as one of the starting props this year, is chief among them.

"There was probably a year or two there where I didn't say too much to him, I was too scared," Smith said.

"I learned a lot from him over the years. He's a big part of why I'm an NRL player and why I'm here today."

Even though he left over the summer for the Warriors after securing a release on compassionate grounds, Fisher-Harris is still showing the way for the Panthers.

Due to COVID and quirks of the NRL draw, Penrith has only played in New Zealand once since 2019.

That game came back in June when the Panthers downed the Warriors 28-18 despite resting their contingent of State of Origin players.

As was the case when they played Jarome Luai at Wests Tigers or Stephen Crichton at Canterbury, the prospect of taking on someone who helped build the empire brought out the best in Penrith, especially for prop Moses Leota, one of Fisher-Harris's best friends, who enjoyed his best game of the season.

At the time, the Panthers were stuck in 11th place on the ladder and were only two matches removed from the bottom of the ladder, but the win felt like the start of something.

"That was a turning point in our year," Smith said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"We'd strung two wins together, but to go over there and win without any of the Origin boys was pretty special."

That victory was the third in what turned out to be a nine-match winning streak that brought Penrith's season back from the dead as they reacquainted themselves with their famed blood and bone style that Fisher-Harris once helped define.

As Penrith got back to the old ways, it kept its chances at a fifth straight title alive.

To do so, they'll have to become just the third team in 117 years of Australian rugby league to win the competition from outside the top four, and even if they're favourites to win on Saturday, the odds are against them like never before.

But according to To'o, the difficulties that lie ahead, both in Auckland and potentially beyond, are exactly what the Panthers need if they're to create yet more history.

"We're taking the long road, so it is something different," To'o said.

"All these challenges we face, it brings the best out of us.

"Not playing there in so long, since 2019, it's another challenge for us and we're keen for it."

title: New rugby competition gives Wallabies hopefuls chance to shine
text:
Australian rugby's latest venture in a third-tier competition begins this weekend, with high hopes that it can be a platform for the future.

Super Rugby AUS, a four-week competition between Australia's four professional rugby franchises, starts on Friday when the NSW Waratahs host the Western Force.

With the four professional teams on board, Rugby Australia is attempting to have a third-tier competition succeed where the previous four attempts since the mid-1990s have failed.

RA's domestic comp must avoid familiar hurdles Photo shows Tim Ryan scores a try for the Reds against the Brumbies. Super Rugby AUS — to act as the third tier of the men's professional game in Australia — makes sense, but it must steer clear of the pitfalls that saw previous attempts at such a tournament bite the dust.

The competition provides meaningful competition for players on the brink of Wallabies selection, with a European tour at the end of the season.

But with Australia's best currently in camp for the Rugby Championship, Super Rugby AUS presents an opportunity for the next generation of potential Wallabies to gain valuable experience with, and against, established names.

Players like Tom Robinson and James Martens, both members of the Australian side that placed fifth at this year's World Rugby U20 Championship, get their chance this week to test themselves against some of the country's best players.

Robinson and Martens will line up for the Queensland Reds this Sunday at Ballymore against the ACT Brumbies, after making their debut for the senior side last month against Tonga.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Robinson, 19, is a physically imposing backrower who captained Australia's under-18s to a victory over New Zealand Schools last October.

Now, the opportunity to test himself against Super Rugby talent is one the teenager believes will push not only himself, but other emerging talent.

"It's massive. I think there's a bunch of players around my age, sort of looking to push to that sort of Super Rugby level, like one day, and obviously Wallabies after that," he told ABC Sport.

"[It is] just a great opportunity to get to play at a high level and mesh with people who are seasoned players and have done it at the highest level, which I think will force us to rise and then hopefully go from there."

Martens, 20, is a scrumhalf who showed off quick thinking and vision during Queensland's match against Tonga last month.

Loading Instagram content

A stand-out this season for the GPS club in Brisbane's Premier Grade competition, Martens is expected to come off the bench for the Reds this Sunday.

Speaking to ABC Sport, he said the exposure of professional set-ups and the opportunity to continue playing against high-level competition at the end of the club season was an exciting proposition for young players striving to break into Super Rugby.

"The more footy you play, the better you get, and the more footy at a higher level, as well, definitely helps," he said.

"The exposure that we get from this, and hopefully the time that we'll be able to get on the field with the people around us, will just help improve us so much faster."

Super Rugby AUS also gives those on the cusp of Wallabies selection a chance to shine and be noticed for Test matches at the end of the season.

Massimo De Lutiis, 21, was a surprise selection in Joe Schmidt's January squad despite not having made his Super Rugby Pacific debut.

Massimo De Lutiis wants to use Super Rugby AUS as a platform to break into future Wallabies' squads. (AAP: Darren England)

The Reds' prop forward went on to play nine matches for the Reds in 2025 before suffering a fractured wrist in May.

The young tighthead, who played alongside current Wallabies Tom Hooper, Tom Lynagh and Corey Toole for Australia A last year, said Super Rugby AUS was an opportunity for him to get back in contention for international consideration.

"For this Super Rugby AUS, we made a rule that we're just going to compete with each other, like, we're not going to go easy on each other no matter what. We're competing for that first spot," he told media on Wednesday.

"Obviously [playing for the] Wallabies is on the radar, and these are the games to prove myself. I'm going to be putting my hat in the ring for that.

"The more rugby, the better, that's all I can say. I think all the boys are keen. I know every other state's going to be keen to go."

Super Rugby AUS round one

Friday, September 12

NSW Waratahs vs Western Force, 7:30pm, Warringah Rugby Club, Warriewood, Sydney

Sunday, September 14

Queensland Reds vs ACT Brumbies, 3pm, Ballymore Stadium, Herston, Brisbane

title: Defence quietly axes new ammunition procurement with Thales Australia
text:
The Department of Defence has quietly axed a procurement process with Thales Australia that promised to scale up production at the company's Benalla munitions facility in north-east Victoria.

Under the deal, Thales was set to manufacture 155-millimetre M795 artillery ammunition.

At a National Press Club address last year, Minister for Defence Industry Pat Conroy said the Benalla factory would be the "first dedicated facility outside the United States to manufacture this artillery round".

Pat Conroy announced the deal at the National Press Club in Canberra in October last year. (AAP Image/Mick Tsikas)

Mr Conroy said it would produce 15,000 rounds a year by 2028, with the capacity to scale up to 100,000 rounds and support 550 jobs.

But in June this year, the Department of Defence issued a media release — omitting references to Thales or Benalla — saying it would "cease the current procurement activity" and "refine" requirements before "reapproaching the market".

The department said there had been "notable changes in the global defence industrial base" since the tender was awarded in 2023.

"This has included a surge in international demand for naval five-inch and a significant increase in global capacity to produce 155mm projectiles," the statement read.

It said the changes required defence to "re-assess" the manufacture of 155mm projectiles.

Pat Conroy (second from left) at an earlier meeting with Thales Australia executives in Bendigo. (ABC Central Victoria: Tyrone Dalton)

"Defence remains committed to working with industry to deliver a 155mm M795 forging capability by 2028, producing 15,000 rounds each year, with further additional capacity that will be determined as part of the re-approach to market," the statement read.

In a statement, a Thales spokesperson said the company was aware of the department's decision "to re-assess its manufacturing approach on 155mm M795 ammunition".

"As a guided weapons and explosive ordnance (GWEO) strategic partner, we are continuing to work with the department on its reassessed 155mm requirements," she said.

Thales employees assembling 5.56mm ball ammunition on a production line at Benalla. (Supplied: Department of Defence )

Local disappointment

The Australian Manufacturing Workers Union has more than 100 members at Thales Australia in Benalla.

Organiser Danny Miller said with jobs disappearing from the Goulburn Valley, the news of the deal's cancellation was "certainly a kick in the guts".

Danny Miller says the cancellation is a "kick in the guts" amid job losses in the region. (Supplied)

"Jobs have disappeared and there are not replacement jobs being put in place by all companies, including the government," he said.

He said the government needed to build defence capabilities at home.

"Australia needs to build this capability on our shores and not have dependence on foreign countries to supply our defence forces to protect our sovereignty, should the worst-case scenarios play out," he said.

"Spending should come to local jobs and local capabilities, which is something that has been significantly diminished since privatisation occurred."

State MP for Euroa Annabelle Cleeland said investment in the broader community had been flagged as part of the partnership.

The Nationals MP said she had hoped this would lead to more housing for the region.

"During meetings that were held with contractors, we were told that a portion of investment would … go back into the local community as a kind of legacy project," she said.

Annabelle Cleeland says she had hoped the project would lead to more housing for the area. (Supplied: Annabelle Cleeland)

"In the meetings, we spoke about the areas of biggest need for these projects — and [at] the top were housing to avoid major shifts in the local rental market, the need for relevant TAFE courses to upskill locals, and funding for accommodations for Benalla Health."

She was concerned about the way the announcement was made.

"I am appalled about the way the Labor government has gone about … announcing this," she said.

" It reeks, to be honest. "

'Bigger and better' project possible

Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) executive director Justin Bassi said the decision, announced late on a Friday, suggested the government wanted little media attention.

But he was optimistic about greater opportunities for defence industry if the project went back out to tender, as suggested in the department's June announcement.

He said conflict overseas, specifically Russia's war on Ukraine, had created a surge in demand for ammunition like 155mm projectiles.

Justin Bassi is optimistic about greater opportunities for defence industry if the project goes back out to tender. (Supplied: ASPI)

"The changes in the international environment, where many countries were realising that they had no stockpiles or their stockpiles were rapidly decreasing because of their important support for Ukraine … that was having an impact on the global supply," he said.

"And so defence was suggesting that they needed to take a re-look at what their request was before going back out to market."

Mr Bassi said governments should be able to pivot in response to international changes, and that the project's second incarnation could be "bigger and better".

The original announcement for 15,000 rounds a year was not sufficient in his view, as Australia needed enough stockpile for its own purposes beyond training.

"Hopefully the new project, whenever it is announced, has a far greater desired capacity," he said.

Fresh call for defence spending boost

The Department of Defence's relationship with Thales came under scrutiny last year after a $1.2 billion contract awarded to the French weapons manufacturer was referred to the corruption watchdog.

In a statement, Shadow Minister for Defence Jacinta Nampijinpa Price said the ceasing of the procurement was "disappointing".

Jacinta Nampijinpa Price says the scrapping of the procurement deal is disappointing. (AAP: Mick Tsikas)

"At a time when we need weapons and munitions at speed and scale, the Albanese government continues to move at a snail's pace," she said

"There would be greater certainty for defence industry if the government followed the Coalition's call to increase defence spending to at least 3 per cent of GDP, to fund the capabilities we need as per the government's own plans and strategies."

The Minister for Defence Industry has been contacted for comment.

title: Trump's trade tariffs rush to Supreme Court
text:
The Supreme Court has granted an unusually quick hearing on President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, setting up a major test of his economic and trade agenda.

The court agreed to take up an appeal from the Trump administration after lower courts found most of his tariffs were illegal.

The small businesses and states that challenged them also agreed to the accelerated timetable.

They say Mr Trump's import taxes on goods from almost every country in the world have nearly driven their businesses to bankruptcy.

The justices will hear the case in November, a lightning-fast timetable by the Supreme Court's typical standard.

The tariffs will stay in place in the meantime.

Donald Trump's power to impose tariffs

"Congress, not the president alone, has the power to impose tariffs," attorney Jeffrey Schwab, from the Liberty Justice Center said.

Two lower courts agreed that Mr Trump did not have the power to impose all the tariffs under an emergency powers law, though a divided appeals court left them in place.

Donald Trump has cited longstanding trade deficits as an emergency. (AP: Mark Schiefelbein)

The Trump administration asked the justices to intervene quickly, arguing the law gave him the power to regulate imports and that striking down Is Trump about to create the next great financial crisis?

The case will come before a court that has been reluctant to check Trump's extraordinary flex of executive power.

One big question is whether the justices' own expansive view of presidential authority allows for Trump's tariffs without the explicit approval of Congress, which the Constitution endows with the power to levy tariffs.

Three of the justices on the conservative-majority court were nominated by Mr Trump in his first term.

'Economic catastrophe'

While the tariffs have raised fears of higher prices and slower economic growth, Mr Trump has also used them to pressure other countries into accepting new trade deals.

Trump leveraging peacekeeping in tariff 'deals' across Asia Photo shows Two men speak at a press conference at the White House. With Thailand, Cambodia, and Pakistan receiving reduced tariff rates in Donald Trump's latest negotiations, it appears there is a pattern of "good deals" among those who accept his intervention in the region.

Revenue from tariffs totalled $US159 billion ($242 billion) by late August, more than double what it was at the same point a year earlier.

Solicitor General D John Sauer has argued that the lower court rulings are already affecting those trade negotiations.

If the tariffs are struck down, the US Treasury might take a hit by having to refund some of the import taxes it has collected, the president's administration has said.

A ruling against them could even impair the nation's ability to reduce the flow of fentanyl and efforts to end Russia's war against Ukraine, Mr Sauer argued.

The administration did win over four appeals court judges, who found the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act let the president regulate importation during emergencies without explicit limitations.

In recent decades, Congress has ceded some tariff authority to the president and Mr Trump has made the most of the power vacuum.

Add to your watchlist Photo shows Mystery Road Origin ABC iview with young detective Jay Swan in the bush. The critically acclaimed Mystery Road: Origin returns as Detective Jay Swan (Mark Coles Smith) and Mary (Tuuli Narkle) uncover dark secrets in a haunted timber town, where the past threatens to tear them apart.

The case involves two sets of import taxes, both of which Mr Trump justified by declaring a national emergency: the tariffs first announced in April and the ones from February on imports from Canada, China and Mexico.

It does not include his levies on foreign steel, aluminium and vehicles, or the tariffs Mr Trump imposed on China in his first term that were kept by Democratic President Joe Biden.

The president can impose tariffs under other laws, but those have more limitations on the speed and severity with which he can act.

AP/Reuters

title: NSW government cracks down on childcare safety under new reforms
text:
High-risk providers will be required to publish their compliance history and penalties for safety breaches will increase by up to 900 per cent under a suite of changes proposed by the NSW government.

The reforms are among more than 30 proposed changes to childcare legislation designed to close loopholes in the sector and bolster the powers of the regulatory authority.

If the government's bill, expected to be introduced to parliament on Wednesday, is passed the regulator will be able to suspend or revoke quality ratings during or following an investigation, while high-risk services will be required to display their compliance measures.

The announcement follows an extensive probe by the ABC into allegations of safety concerns and regulation breaches in childcare centres across Australia.

Acting Education and Early Learning Minister Courtney Houssos said the proposal will also triple infringement penalties for small providers and expand the number of offences for which fines apply.

For large providers that operate 25 or more services, penalties for safety breaches will increase by 900 per cent.

"This bill will give the regulator the powers to act when it needs to," Ms Houssos said.

"Importantly, it will also allow the regulator to give more information to parents about the compliance history of a centre and the actions the regulator has taken."

Courtney Houssos said the reforms would give the NSW regulatory authority more power to act. (Facebook: NSW Legislative Council)

The minister said the legislation would build on reforms that were agreed to at a national meeting of state and federal education ministers last month and funnel $55 million to boost frontline staff.

The NSW regulator, which was significantly constrained by national laws, would also now have the legal obligation to put the rights and best interests of children above all else.

In NSW, state MLC Abigail Boyd invoked a standing order to state parliament last November to compel the education department to release internal documents on how the regulator had handled childcare breaches.

A parliamentary inquiry into childcare, chaired by Ms Boyd, began last month and sought to look at regulatory and policy inaction, while making recommendations to "re-establish trust in early childhood services in NSW", she said.

Quality standards in childcare are set by the Commonwealth, but states and territories regulate the sector.

title: Fishers left reeling by Exmouth Gulf Marine Park announcement
text:
Recreational fishers and commercial guides fear being locked out of some of Western Australia's most pristine waters under state government plans to protect the Exmouth Gulf as a marine park.

Premier Roger Cook said last week the conservation area would encompass all 2,600-square-kilometres of the gulf, with 30 per cent to be designated as no-catch sanctuary zones.

Adjacent to the Ningaloo Reef, 30 per cent of the Exmouth Gulf will be made no-catch sanctuary zones. (ABC News)

Andy Sutton has fished in the Exmouth Gulf for 22 years, where he leads sport and fly-fishing tours.

He said the lack of detail around the 30 per cent figure was "unnerving".

"We can lose a lot out of this, and it's all going to depend on where this 30 per cent is," Mr Sutton said.

Andy Sutton says the announcement puts his business of 20 years at risk. (Supplied: Andy Sutton)

He worried smaller charters had been overlooked in the three years of advisory work by the Exmouth Gulf Taskforce, which counted international prawner Seaharvest and WA's peak recreational fishing body, Recfishwest among its members.

Mr Sutton's business mainly operates along the shallow flats of the gulf's eastern and southern margins — areas he would like to see remain accessible.

"We're probably going to be the real losers in the whole lot," he said.

Lessons from south coast

Recfishwest chief executive Andrew Rowland labelled the commitment to a no-catch sanctuary zone a "political" move.

"We believe [the pledge is] premature, before even going out and talking to the broader community," he said.

The Exmouth Gulf is a recognised biodiversity hotspot and home to fish, coral, and other species. (Supplied: Blue Media)

The organisation refused to endorse a "whole-of-gulf" marine park before the announcement.

But the taskforce ultimately recommended this in its report to Environment Minister Matthew Swinbourn in June.

"At the time, we were going through the South Coast [Marine Park] process, and the wheels had really fallen off," Dr Rowland said.

Final plans for the South Coast Marine Park were released in late 2024, after a highly divisive three-year process.

Dr Rowland implored the state government to avoid the same mistakes.

"The marine park planning team [must] understand where those areas of importance for fishing are, [so] that can be factored into the design process before the draft is put out to public comment," he said.

Andrew Rowland has slammed the 30 per cent target as "political". (Supplied)

Eastern side 'incredibly important'

WA Marine Science Institution research director Jenny Shaw conducted a comprehensive knowledge review on behalf of the taskforce.

Dr Shaw said the globally significant environmental values of the gulf justified the level of protection put forward by the state government.

"In terms of the 30 per cent, I think that's … a great aspirational figure," she said.

Dr Shaw highlighted the gulf's eastern section of mangroves and tidal flats as "incredibly important".

She believes these areas are likely to host no-catch sanctuary zones.

Mangroves along the gulf's eastern edges form habitats and nurseries for marine life. (Supplied: Blue Media)

It is understood the Department of Biodiversity, Conservation, and Attractions is finalising its "marine values" map of Exmouth Gulf for release later this week.

The online tool, collated from survey responses gathered earlier this year, aims to visualise how and where the gulf is being used by the public.

With the consultation process expected to continue for up to 18 months, fishers like Mr Sutton hope the right balance can still be struck.

"We love [the gulf], almost to the point where you almost take ownership of something," he said.

title: 'Illegal' protest shortens another Vuelta a España stage
text:
Pro-Palestinian protesters disrupted the Vuelta a España again on Tuesday as Colombian Egan Bernal (Ineos Grenadiers) won stage 16, which ended 8km before the scheduled finish at Castro de Herville.

Jonas Vingegaard retained the overall lead despite a late puncture. Aussie Jai Hindley remains in fourth place after finishing in the main group of leaders, 6 minutes down on the stage winner.

The race directors announced on Radio Vuelta that due to a "big protest at 3 kilometres before the [finish] line", the stage winner would be decided early.

The race had entered the final 15km at the time of the announcement, with Bernal and Spain's Mikel Landa (Soudal Quick-Step) out in front, and the Colombian won the sprint to the new finish line, with Brieuc Rolland (Groupama-FDJ) coming in third.

Egan Bernal won the truncated stage. (Getty Images: Tim de Waele)

A large group of protesters, waving Palestinian flags, had completely blocked the road on the ascent to the line. The finish was moved to the foot of the climb, on the 167.9 km ride from Poio to Mos.Castro de Herville.

"It's a victory and after the drop from the GC, I really wanted a win," Bernal said.

"In the end, with Landa the cooperation was super good and when we knew that the final would be with 8 kilometres left, we were like, 'OK, so we just sprint.'"

The peloton had been content to allow the riders up ahead to stay away, but on the penultimate climb, the main bunch began to split, with the general classification contenders forming their own group.

"It's a shame that this has happened again," Vingegaard said.

" Everyone has the right to protest, but it's unfortunate that it had to happen here and in this way, preventing us from finishing the race. "

Previously, there was no winner on stage 11, after organisers ordered the race to finish 3km from the line due to pro-Palestinian protesters causing disruption at the finish in Bilbao.

Team Israel-Premier Tech have been targeted throughout the Vuelta. (Getty Images: Tim de Waele)

Protesters are railing against the continued participation in the race by the Israel-Premier Tech team.

The team is privately owned with no official connection to the state, however, its co-owner, Sylvan Adams, has called himself a "self-appointed ambassador-at-large for Israel".

There were incidents on stage 10 that caused a rider to crash and also during stage five's team time trial, when the Israel-Premier Tech team were stopped on the road by a group of protesters holding Palestinian flags.

Israel-Premier Tech removed its name from riders' jerseys on Saturday, but the protests have continued, with Javier Romo (Movistar) suffering a crash on Sunday's stage 15.

The Spanish rider was not at the start of Tuesday's stage, abandoning the race due to injuries picked up in the crash after a man with a Palestinian flag tried to run up to the riders and a policeman ran across the road towards the spectator.

Race director Javier Guillen said the intention was still to finish the race in Madrid on Sunday as planned and called the repeated disruptions illegal.

Protesters organised themselves 3km from the scheduled finish line. (Getty Images: Europa Press/Adrian Irago)

"I'm here before you because, from La Vuelta, we want to clearly express our strongest rejection of what we experienced today," Guillen told reporters.

"Fortunately, the stage was completed in terms of timing and the stage winner but, obviously, the stage did not end where we had planned.

"The main message I want to share with you today is that we are going to continue with La Vuelta, and tomorrow we will start the next stage.

"You cannot cut stages short, you cannot block the cyclists' path.

"It's illegal because it's defined as such both in the Penal Code and in the Sports Law. We are a sport and sport is meant to unite, anything that doesn't serve that purpose isn't linked to sport.

"We want to defend our sport, we want to defend our race, and that's why we want to keep working."

There have been calls to suspend the Israel-Premier Tech team from the race, but Guillen reiterated the Vuelta's stance that this was a decision that was out of the organisers' hands.

"Yesterday, there was a match between Italy and Israel. A football match was played, and a European Cup in which Israel participated has taken place," Guillen said following Monday's soccer World Cup qualifier played in Hungary.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"The participation of these teams is not prohibited because no international federation has done so, none. And there hasn't been any international body that has imposed sanctions requiring us, the world of sport, to act accordingly.

"From now on, what we want is for the race to continue because all the teams participating in La Vuelta have legitimacy."

Guillen said the Vuelta is deploying every possible resource when it comes to security, but it is impossible to cover every area in a race of this size. The director was asked if a Plan B was in place for Sunday's final stage.

"No Plan B for reaching Madrid, no replacing the Madrid stage, absolutely not," Guillen replied.

The Gaza war began after Palestinian militant group Hamas carried out an attack on southern Israel on October 7, 2023, killing about 1,200 people according to Israeli authorities.

Israel's subsequent campaign has levelled entire neighbourhoods in Gaza, displaced most of the population of 2.3 million and pushed the enclave to the brink of famine, according to the United Nations, killing over 63,000 Palestinians.

Reuters

title: Live: NAB to slash 410 jobs and hire more workers overseas
text:
Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's finance blog. I'll be your guide for the next few hours.

It looks like the local share market will have a fairly uninspiring start to the day, with ASX futures trading flat.

The Australian dollar is trading at 65.85 US cents, which is practically flat.

Oil prices rose after Israel launched an air strike on Hamas's political leaders in Qatar's capital, Doha (who were reportedly meeting to discuss the latest Gaza ceasefire proposal).

Another Wall Street record

Meanwhile, it was another record-breaking session on US markets with the Dow Jones (up 0.4%), S & P 500 (up 0.3%) and Nasdaq Composite (up 0.4%) close at their highest levels ever.



The optimism on Wall Street seems to be driven by another case of: "bad news (for the economy) equals good news (for the stock market".

It turns out the US jobs market is in much worse shape than initially thought.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) published some revised data that showed the total number of workers hired in the 12 months to March was much less than expected.

In fact, it was 911,000 fewer workers than the BLS initially stated.

This was the largest downward revision of the US job numbers since at least 2002, and it shows the American labour market was already slowing down during Joe Biden's presidency (even before Donald Trump announced his "Liberation Day" tariffs).

As a result, markets are pricing in a 100% chance of the US Federal Reserve cutting interest rates at its board meeting later this month.

The question is not whether the Fed will slash rates, but by how much it will reduce them.

There are an increasing number of economists predicting it might be a 0.5 percentage point cut (double the usual)!

title: Recovering gambling addict wants 'moral' use for pokies millions
text:
Bec Healey loved the atmosphere of the gaming rooms.

The flashing lights, the chimes and the bells of the poker machines helped her to "tune out from everything" and forget her problems for a while.

"I could go there and I could just listen and be encompassed by all the sounds and the atmosphere going on in the gaming rooms," she said.

The Mount Gambier mother started playing pokies casually but soon fell into an addiction which ruined her life for two years.

Ms Healey said her mental health took a "massive dive" and at the height of her gambling she "couldn't get off the couch".

"It consumes you. It's like this black cloud over your head … you literally can't do anything," she said.

" It got to the point where I couldn't be there for my child. "

Recent data showed South Australians are now putting more than $1 billion through the pokies, crossing that threshold for the first time this year and up nearly $53 million from the previous 12 months.

The state government made more than $450 million from those losses.

Pokies a mother's 'kryptonite'

Losses were particularly high in regional areas, with the combined Mount Gambier and Grant local government areas losing $24 million, about $720 per person.

Ms Healey, 42, described the pokies as her "kryptonite" and estimated she lost thousands of dollars gambling to escape the pressures of being a single parent to a child with a disability and her own mental health issues.

She always gambled on payday.

The important bills would get paid, but she would "just blow" the rest and when she was on a winning streak she would "be in there more often than not".

Her addiction quickly became a "perpetual cycle" of borrowing money from family and friends and "robbing Peter to pay Paul".

"I would then have to worry about how I was going to feed myself and my child and get to the next pay," she said.

It was only after she won and lost $2,000 in one day that Ms Healey realised things had to change.

"[I felt] devastated and really disappointed with myself that I could do that. And that was the problem, I couldn't stop myself," she said.

Recent data shows poker machine losses in South Australian have risen by $53 million from the previous 12 months. (Pixabay)

More funds needed

Project officer of the Gambling Help Service with Lifeline South East Louise Murphy said the amount of time people could spend gambling was a concern.

"Over 20 hours a day, our venues are open in Mount Gambier, so people experiencing gambling harm don't get to have much of a break," she said.

Louise Murphy wants more of the government gambling profits to go to harm reduction. (ABC South East SA: Josh Brine)

The Greens recently called on the SA government to phase out all pokies by 2030.

Ms Murphy thought it would be difficult for governments to turn away from the revenue pokies brought in.

But she wanted more of that money to be spent on services to help people facing addiction.

An auditor general report from 2023 showed just one per cent — $5.38 million — of all gambling revenue received by the state government went back into the Gamblers Rehabilitation Fund.

"Indexing what they spend on harm to the revenue raised on gambling would be really helpful for service providers," Ms Murphy said.

Consumer and Business Affairs Minister Andrea Michaels said rather than banning gaming machines, the focus was on "supporting those who experience gambling-related harm" and reducing the number of machines in the state.

The minister did not comment on the Gamblers Rehabilitation Fund.

'Massive problem'

Ms Healey eventually found help with her addiction through Lifeline and now works with the service to help others.

Bec Healy wants to see the state government take a "moral" stand on gambling harm. (ABC South East SA: Josh Brine)

She said it would be "moral" to ban pokies outright and wants to see more done to help people experiencing addiction.

"To think large amounts of money like that are going through those machines, it's pretty devastating," she said.

"How many other people are in the position I was in?

"It's a massive problem … I think more could be put back into helping."

title: Cummins hails bowling depth despite injury concerns
text:
Pat Cummins insists Australia have enough depth to cover any injuries to their pace cartel in the Ashes, as the struck-down quick sets a loose target for his bowling return.

Cummins has felt a lingering soreness in his back since Australia's Test series win in the West Indies almost two months ago, with scans since showing lumbar bone stress.

The 32-year-old is desperate to feature in this summer's Ashes and has vowed to take an aggressive approach to prove his fitness if required.

A timeline has not yet been set for Cummins's on-field return and he is prepared to go into the Test summer without playing a Sheffield Shield game if required.

But the quick said he would likely want to be back bowling at least a month before the first Test against England in Perth on November 21.

"I'd imagine [I'd want to be bowling] at minimum a month out, maybe six weeks," Cummins said.

"But I've not thought that deeply about it yet.

"It's still a bit of a wait and see. We've got plenty of time, so we'll map a way back when we get closer.

"At the moment for the next few weeks it's pretty light. Not much running and zero bowling."

Lance Morris has been rulled out of the Ashes with a back injury. (Getty Images: Paul Kane)

Cummins's injury scare has highlighted concerns around Australia's depth for the summer.

Scott Boland remains the fourth member of the cartel and is ready to step up in case of injury, but below him numbers are dwindling.

Speedster Lance Morris has been ruled out of the summer, requiring his own back surgery, while Jhye Richardson's Ashes availability is questionable on return from a dislocated shoulder.

Rising Queensland quick Callum Vidler has also been sidelined for the long term with a back injury, while fellow young star Mahli Beardman is nursing a stress fracture.

"We feel really well placed," Cummins insisted.

"A lot of planning goes in. It's not just a month before; it's 12 months out.

"Someone like Jhye Richardson hopefully he will be available for some of the summer.

"There's [Michael] Neser, Brendan Doggett was part of squads last year, Sean Abbott. So I'm really confident in our depth.

"Obviously there is a bit of Shield cricket and white-ball cricket before that to make sure everyone is up and raring to go."

Michael Neser remains in the wings as an option for the Australians. (Getty Images: Sarah Reed)

England are gaining fitness ahead of the Ashes.

Speedster Jofra Archer returned to Test cricket in July and sent down a devastating 4-18 from nine overs against South Africa in a one-day international earlier this week.

Can't get enough cricket from Grandstand? Tune in for the latest cricket news, interviews and analysis from the ABC team in the Grandstand Cricket Podcast.

"[He's] got quicker. It was box-office bowling," England coach Brendan McCullum remarked afterwards.

"I thought it was brilliant and, not just his pace but his skill, his ability to shift it both ways and to test batters with the steep bounce he gets.

"He's a proper cricketer, hence why we've taken our time with him to make sure that we give him every chance to be in the biggest series of all of our lives.

"He's going to be a huge player when we get to Australia, as a number of others are."

The tourists also expected to have fellow express quick Mark Wood on deck, while Ben Stokes has also resumed training following a shoulder injury.

Chris Woakes, who was man of the series in the 2023 Ashes, has also not given up hope of playing after opting against surgery on his dislocated shoulder.

AAP

title: 'Heat challenges' to impact Tokyo World Championships
text:
World Athletics president Lord Sebastian Coe has acknowledged the World Championships will face "some heat challenges" when competition gets underway on Saturday in Tokyo.

Japan has endured a stifling summer of record-breaking heat over the past month, with 15 cities recording their highest temperatures since records began in 1898.

During August, 44 of the country's 47 prefectures issued heat stroke warnings, while temperatures in Tokyo were expected to hit 30 degrees Celsius on Saturday, with 75 per cent humidity.

On Sunday, that temperature will rise to a predicted 34C.

The 2021 Olympic marathon took place in Sapporo, but was still very hot. (Getty Images: Lintao Zhang)

Unlike the Olympics in 2021, when endurance events were moved north to Sapporo to avoid the heat, the World Championship will hold the long-distance walking events and marathons in Tokyo.

The 35km race walk will start at 8am, local time (9am AEST), on Saturday.

The women's and men's marathon are also scheduled to start at 8am on Sunday and Monday, respectively.

"I don't think it's any great secret, we do have some heat challenges in Tokyo," Coe said at a press conference on Tuesday.

"I'm very proud to be able to say, with full justification, that we have the most accomplished and the most capable health and science team in any international sport and frankly, any sporting organisation.

"That shouldn't come as a surprise because we have been dealing with some of these challenges for a long time."

Lord Sebastian Coe questioned the inaction of world leaders to mitigate climate change. (Getty Images: Tim Clayton)

Coe said sport was having to take the lead on climate change issues, taking aim at world leaders for their inaction.

"Some of you have heard me talk about the challenges of climate change. These are not transient. They're here to stay," Coe, the British two-time Olympic 1,500m champion in 1980 and 1984, said.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"Governments have not stepped up to the plate, and sport is going to have to take some unilateral judgements and decisions here.

"If we are committed to athlete welfare, then we should probably be openly committed to that."

He added that international sport as a whole will have to "revisit" the global calendar to account for rising temperatures and admitted that there may need to be some flexibility if conditions worsened in Tokyo.

"If we are committed to athlete welfare, then it is inevitable that we are going to have to stage some of our endurance-based events maybe at times of the year that are going to give optimum chances for the athletes, and not leave them in a health or a performance deficit," Coe said.

"But what I can say is that we have the right people in place in Tokyo, and the right discussions taking place if we had to make any adjustments to the timetable in advance of those scheduled events because of these conditions."

title: Friends combine finances to buy dream home together
text:
It's morning tea time at Gem Romuld's Gwynneville home in Wollongong and there are plenty of hands to help wrangle two toddlers, clean up dishes and prepare the food.

That's because Gem lives not only with her partner Dinah Too and their two young children Thea and Marlowe, but also with her friends Lexi Dickson and Renata Field and their nine-year-old son Finnley.

This isn't a university share house — the adults purchased the property together in 2021 and have a co-living arrangement, meaning they co-own and live on the property.

Shopping and food is shared between all seven members of the household. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Hunstdale)

"We never wanted to go into a nuclear family style of living, we wanted to be with other families, with our friends," Gem said.

"Having babies that don't sleep or toddlers is really hard, and I can see how so many other parents feel isolated, but there was just no chance of that happening for us."

A glance around the home reveals a long grocery list on the fridge with details of a shared monthly shop and a chore wheel to designate household jobs.

It was a decision also made for financial reasons.

Morning tea involves plenty of hands to make food and look after children. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Huntsdale)

"We look after each other's kids, we look after each other and of course, it ultimately just meant it was possible to buy a home," Renata said.

Cotality data shows the Wollongong subregion has the highest median house price in regional New South Wales at $1.3 million — a price that has climbed by 50 per cent in the past five years.

"We'd be in a tiny apartment or just wouldn't have been able to purchase a house at all if we were just on our own," Renata said.

The group shares shopping, cooking and chores. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Huntsdale)

With combined finances, the friends have bought and created their dream home; a main house with a granny flat separated by a vegetable garden.

A signed agreement lays out the terms for exit and a shared ethos of community and participation keeps things running smoothly.

"We're really committed to each other and to living together in a shared and equal way," Renata said.

Shared retirement

Just a few suburbs over in Berkeley, another co-living group is preparing to share a different life stage — retirement.

Susy Lee is planning to retire to a large Berkeley home with four other couples. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Susy Lee and her husband Brian have joined four other couples to buy a large, rambling house on a hill, where they're currently spending weekends testing out the new living model.

"Our plan is that all 10 of us will live here full-time during retirement in the next two years," she said.

"That's what we're working towards — we're calling it a crazy experiment."

Susy Lee (second from left) says living with friends will reduce loneliness. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

They're in the process of renovating the home to create five suites with contained bathrooms.

A household constitution sets out an agreement for divesting from the property, and Susy jokes her Masters of Peace and Conflict Studies comes in handy when negotiating big-ticket decisions.

Susy Lee says friendship and support will be a benefit of the shared home. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

"We're doing it for a variety of reasons I suppose, but the main ones would be to combat loneliness and the financial problems of retirement," Susy said.

" Some of us have lost parents in the last year and a half and we've helped each other through that — it's been a real support. "

Barriers to uptake

Cohousing Australia chair Jason Hilder said collective housing models, which included co-living, co-housing — where multiple dwellings were built on a shared property — and co-ops remained unusual in Australia.

"In Australia it's less than 1 per cent," Dr Hilder said.

In some European countries it is much more common — in Sweden more than 20 per cent of housing stock is cooperative housing.

Jason Hilder says a lack of affordable housing is driving alternative living. (ABC Goulburn-Murray: Phillipe Perez)

The Australian Bureau of Statistics predicts group households — which include any living arrangement with two or more non-related and uncoupled adults — will make up 5 per cent of all households in Australia by 2046.

Dr Hilder said interest in collective models was growing due to the lack of affordable and available housing, but legislation and lending restrictions had created barriers.

"State by state, the term 'co-housing' isn't in the legislation," he said.

" There is a code for retirement villages, for boarding houses, even for social housing, but if we were to talk about co-housing or multiple families under one roof, the legislation doesn't cater for that. "

NSW planning legislation defines co-living as a rental accommodation overseen by a property manager, with no mention of the shared ownership models used by the Wollongong households.

Renata Field says more co-living arrangements could help the housing crisis. (ABC Illawarra: Justin Huntsdale)

While some major banks have introduced multi-party loans to cater for shared ownership, those considering a collective arrangement still find finance difficult to secure.

Renata and Gem spent two years trying to find a suitable lender, and the Berkeley couples had to set up a business collective to borrow the money they needed.

Property share is a flexible and practical option for anyone looking to split the cost of a home while maintaining financial independence.

Renata said more people should think outside the box when it came to housing.

"I think this great Australian dream of having a house with two-and-a-half kids on a quarter-acre block, it just can't work for everyone," she said.

"There's not enough resources and there's not enough housing.

"This is not for everyone, but I would encourage people to have conversations with people they love about whether they could imagine it."

title: Andrew Vine is the jockey that racing forgot. He died before his day in court
text:
“When [his mother] Judy dropped him off at Murphy’s Caulfield stables in the mid ’70s, Andrew was officially the smallest and lightest apprentice in Victoria,” Green told a small gathering of family and friends in Federation Chapel at Lilydale Memorial Park. “For the next six or seven years, we slept in adjacent beds in the kids’ dorm. A young Andrew Vine had to give up being a jockey in the early 1980s after breaking his pelvis in a track accident. “We ate our meals together, we worked and rode horses alongside each other, and we gave each other unconditional support through the many challenges of that brutal and chaotic environment.” Vine and Green both entered the stable environment as 14-year-olds, having been granted early exemption from the education department. It was no place for a teenage boy.

They were at the mercy of sadistic and perverted stable staff and because they had been indentured as apprentices by the state’s governing body of racing, felt like they had little choice but to abide. Their treatment was kept as a dark secret for 30 years; they battled drug and alcohol addictions, and their pain was not aired in public until the 2008 “Jockey Ritual Trial” in the County Court. Vine and Green were key prosecution witnesses in a case that led to two Caulfield stable hands – John Finlayson and John William Honeysett – being convicted of indecent assault during the 1970s. “I’ll never forget Andrew’s unwavering supporting testimony that he gave under extreme pressure from a pair of rabid defence lawyers,” Green said. “He was staunch and tough, and he didn’t give an inch.”

Loading Until Vine’s death, he hoped for restitution and accountability. He was to be part of a civil case against Victoria Racing Club, which was racing’s governing body until 2001, seeking redress for historical pain and suffering. Despite his promise to Green to stay alive, he could not reverse his slide into ailing health, and died at home. Vine never had his day in court. Instead, family and friends were left on Friday to make sense of the 64-year-old’s tumultuous life. Vine’s first winner made headlines. He booted home 140-1 shot Tobazari at Caulfield in the late 1970s as an apprentice. But his riding career ended abruptly when he broke his pelvis during a training accident.

He entered the workforce and started a family in the late 1980s – taking in partner Margaret’s children Mark and Tara before having a son of their own, Jesse, in 1992. But the injuries kept coming. Vine broke his neck in a workplace accident around the time his son was born, and eight years later he was clipped by a passing car while helping an elderly woman change a tyre. “He didn’t call an ambulance,” his son Jesse said. “He just walked it off, went home and laid on the floor because he insisted it was less painful than laying in bed. “A few surgeries, and a few years later, his back was still no good.

“He definitely didn’t do himself any favours, not getting any details of anyone that was there, or any witnesses. So he was sort of left to fend for himself. “But that was Andrew. He never wanted to make a fuss.” Former apprentice jockey Andrew Vine was described as a ‘rough diamond’ at his funeral service. Vine and Margaret separated in 1996, but became best friends. He would later become a “stepfather” to her fourth child, Mia, whose own father died in 2007 when she was four and a half years old. “Mia and I moved into Andrew’s, and he looked after myself and Mia like she was his own,” Margaret said.

Vine was described on Friday as a “cool dad” and a “bit of a rough diamond”. He had a “biker period”, worked on cars in his backyard, enjoyed a punt and didn’t mind a go on the pokies. His son even compared him to a hard-living rocker. “When Ozzy Osborne died at the age of 76, I thought, ‘I reckon Dad’s got another good 10 years left at least’. But, yeah, apparently not, Dad,” Jesse said. But above all, Green said, Vine was “decent, kind, generous and unflinchingly loyal”. “He was a proud and devoted father to Jesse, a committed partner to Margaret, a loving son, brother and uncle,” Green said.

“He truly loved animals, and we all know that animal lovers are the very best of people. For me, Andrew is my dearest friend. In many ways, my only true friend, and I’ll never, ever forget him.” Green has now farewelled all three of his former roommates from their horrific Caulfield apprentice days. Three years ago, Vine was one of more than a hundred witnesses, not all of them victims, who took part in a review of historic abuse within the Victorian racing industry. The Office of the Racing Integrity Commissioner released a 78-page paper in September 2023 calling on racing’s three codes – gallops, harness and greyhounds – to draw on “best practice from other sports and industries” to create a redress scheme for victims within 12 months. Racing Victoria announced a “restorative engagement program” for “impacted individuals” last month. It is open for submissions for six months from September 1.

title: The 12 Mosman houses that are making way for up to 100 new apartments
text:
It’s not every day that a stranger will come knocking on your door to convince you to sell your house so they can build a multi-storey $750 million apartment complex.

But that was precisely what happened six months ago when 12 home owners in Sydney’s well-heeled suburb of Mosman were approached by a developer keen to demolish the properties to make room for an amalgamated 5368 square metre site.

The wheels were put in motion soon after, and the sale was finalised three months ago. A block of between six and eight storeys with 80 to 100 apartments will be built on the site, subject to local council and state government approval.

The developer first made contact with the owners six months ago, and the sale was finalised three months later. Credit: Matt Willis

The 12 houses on Brierley Street and Rangers Avenue in Mosman to be stitched together have an average value of $4.36 million, with an average land size of 472 square metres each, according to Domain figures.

title: Does Ange Postecoglou still ‘believe in fairies’? We’re about to find out
text:
Postecoglou and Clough are very different blokes, of course, but are kindred spirits, personally and philosophically. They’re both good for a quote. They’re both combative, possibly too much so. They’re both deep believers in the inherent romance of the game and recognise their role in delivering it to fans by playing romantic football. They’re both magnetic characters who can convince a group of men to buy into a vision and give their all for it. A keen student of football history, there’s little doubt that Postecoglou - now that he has been confirmed as Forest’s new manager - has been not only inspired by Clough on his coaching journey, but will be determined to reach for the stars at the same club, in the same way. Brian Clough shakes hands with Forest chairman Jim Willmer at his appointment in 1975. Credit: Press Association Photos Before we get too positive, it’s worth pointing out the potholes ahead for Postecoglou in his Premier League return. There’s one big one in particular.

Evangelos Marinakis, Forest’s owner, seems like a pretty combustible guy. There are, let’s say, some ethical concerns when it comes to his background. He fell out publicly with Postecoglou’s predecessor, Nuno Espirito Santo, and has a track record at both Forest and Olympiacos (one of the other clubs he owns), which suggests a shortage of patience. There’s a bit of Trump-Musk about this union, an unholy alliance between two powerful, larger-than-life characters. This, too, could blow up as spectacularly. The early predictions are that this will end in tears - but don’t discount the possibility that they might be happy tears. Marinakis at a Nottingham Forest game last season. Credit: Getty Images Let’s give them both a bit of credit here. Marinakis isn’t blind; he saw everything Tottenham Hotspur did in Postecoglou’s two-year stint, from his spectacular start to last season’s 22 league defeats and 17th-placed league finish, from which the most reactionary sections of the British press have entirely separated from any sense of context (ie. injuries! They’re a thing!). He saw the “suicidal” high defensive line against Chelsea. He also saw that they finished fifth in 2023-24. Yes, their last league campaign fizzled, but Postecoglou left Spurs with their first European trophy in decades, and a platform that Thomas Frank is now building on.

Marinakis will have had personal explanations from Postecoglou about all the extenuating circumstances. He knows exactly what kind of manager he has just appointed, and we presume he has done so because he likes everything he brings to the table, and wants that for his club.
