title: ‘Really tough’: Hopes fade for Skelton’s Bledisloe return
text:
Will Skelton’s return for the Bledisloe Cup series could rest on the Wallabies breaking a 39-year hoodoo in Auckland after the giant lock revealed it would be logistically “tough” for him to get back and play in the first Test at Eden Park later this month.

Skelton was outstanding for the Wallabies in the Lions series, and also played a big role in the Wallabies’ winning at Ellis Park for the first time in 62 years last month. But Skelton subsequently returned to his French club side La Rochelle ahead of the Top 14 season.

Rugby Australia was hopeful Skelton may return for the Wallabies’ two Tests against the All Blacks on September 27 in Auckland, and in Perth on October 4, and have been in ongoing discussions with La Rochelle coach Ronan O’Gara.

But the likelihood of Skelton playing in the Bledisloe Cup series appears to have dwindled, with the 150kg lock telling the Kick Offs and Kick Ons (KOKO) podcast on Tuesday that his Top 14 schedule had him playing on Sunday, September 21 (5am Monday AEST).

title: WA news LIVE: Man fighting for life after Baldivis stabbing
text:
Premier Roger Cook has just faced a grilling from ABC Perth radio host Nadia Mitsopoulos over a growing opposition to the state government’s proposed racetrack along the Burswood foreshore.

Cook acknowledged the proposal had divided opinion, but that major infrastructure projects were often opposed before they were built, citing how he once opposed Optus Stadium and the Graham Farmer Freeway, which he now uses frequently.

“We’ve got a consultation process, and we continue to work through our own processes ... Let’s be really clear on this, this isn’t something that’s come out of the woodwork in the last fortnight, we campaigned on this in the election campaign,” he said.

“We won every seat adjacent to it ... so if I abandon it today, you might be interviewing me saying, why are you breaking one of your election promises, Premier? Why are you turning your back on that community when you made a commitment to them at the election?”

The Premier and radio host then shared an awkward exchange.

Cook: Once a year, we propose we hold a marquee motorsports event. Now motorsports isn’t everyone’s cup of tea, but it’s a lot of people’s cup of tea.

Mitsopoulos: Well, if it’s your cup of tea, and you love it, you can give me a call ....

Cook [interrupting]: ... No, it’s not my cup of tea.

Mitsopoulos: You looked comfortable in that car.

title: Inside the bitter feud that defined the Lions-Suns rivalry
text:
Save Log in , register or subscribe to save articles for later. Save articles for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time. Got it Normal text size Larger text size Very large text size The bitter rivalry between Touk Miller and Dayne Zorko has defined the ferocity of their derby clashes for seven years, as the pair prepare to face off in the most crucial battle in Queensland’s AFL history. In the Gold Coast Suns’ fledgling days, when the QClash struggled for relevancy in a state dominated by rugby league, the on-field feud between the two competitors helped ignite a genuine intrastate rivalry. Their history dates back to early 2018, when Miller held his Brisbane Lions’ rival to just 10 touches while finishing with 21 disposals of his own to win the second of his four Marcus Ashcroft Medals – the award for the best player on ground in the Queensland derby. The midfielder patted Zorko on the back and offered a handshake, which the latter refused. When they met later that year, their battle was bruising, with Zorko gaining the upper hand in a tight Lions win. Brisbane’s veteran was spotted laughing at Miller as he extended his hand. The tension escalated further in 2023.

Advertisement

Despite being cleared by the match review officer in round 20 of that season, an AFL investigation led to Miller receiving a one-game suspension for “conduct unbecoming” after contacting Zorko’s groin in a tackle. Miller, now 29, admitted he harboured hatred for the defending premiers yet could not help but praise his nemesis. Loading “[Zorko’s] a fantastic player – I respect the way he goes about it on the field – and I’m sure we’re going to clash at some point,” Miller said, as his Suns prepared for a semi-final showdown with Brisbane. “It’ll probably spark a bit of crowd noise, but it just adds to the fuel for the rivalry. “In games like this, you separate yourself from what’s been said in the past. “We probably haven’t gone at it for quite some time now, to be really honest with you. That patch where we did have a good two- or three-year span, I was tagging him for quite some time.”

Advertisement

For the past 15 years, only competition points had been at stake between the two sides. Now, a preliminary final beckons. The Lions seek retribution for their Geelong humbling, while the Suns aim to mark their maiden finals foray with a deep September run after their one-point triumph over Fremantle. Has Dayne Zorko’s shift to the backline all but ended his battles with Touk Miller? We will find out on Saturday. Credit: via Getty Images Suns legend Gary Ablett Junior said with a laugh that he was “not going to add” to the notion the Miller-Zorko rivalry could rear again, but he warned the most composed outfit would emerge victorious. “Touk’s a competitor, and so is Zorko – they’re the type of guys you want on your team. They want to win,” Ablett Jnr said.

Advertisement

Loading “I’m a big believer it doesn’t matter what game you’re playing in – whether it be regular season games or finals – you need to be preparing the same way. “That’s always the challenge, making sure the players are preparing the way they normally would … and then when you get into the game, you’ve got to stay composed. “You’ve got to be able to play instinctive footy and read the game.” Levi Ashcroft will have the chance to step up in Lachie Neale’s absence. Credit: AFL Photos via Getty Images A hamstring injury kept Miller sidelined when the Suns last faced the Lions – a 66-point Gold Coast demolition masterminded by Matt Rowell (37 disposals, 15 clearances). But Miller is ready to rise again on Saturday. While the Suns have won just eight of 29 QClashes, he has averaged 21.12 disposals, 4.82 clearances and 5.24 tackles from 17 games, while kicking seven goals.

Advertisement

“Rivalries probably always bring out the best in most people,” he said. “I’ve been here for long enough to learn that every time we get a chance to have a go at them, I’m always going to try my best to get us the win.” The midfield battle could well decide this contest, where rookie Levi Ashcroft has been tipped to join brother Will Ashcroft, Josh Dunkley and Hugh McCluggage in filling the void left by Lachie Neale’s season-ending calf injury. Loading “It’s a massive void, but we’re confident in our youth,” Dunkley said. “Levi Ashcroft plays on the wing, I’ve talked about him being really selfless and one of the guys who will put his hand up this week to take that role. “Whoever fills the void will do a good job.”

Advertisement

title: Hawks coach has face-to-face meeting with Merrett
text:
Hawthorn coach Sam Mitchell and Essendon captain Zach Merrett have met face-to-face amid reports that the skipper is unhappy at the Bombers and keen for a move to a new club.

Two competition sources have confirmed that Merrett and Mitchell met face-to-face after the Bombers’ season finished, with the Essendon skipper moving closer to the exit at Tullamarine.

Zach Merrett has met with Sam Mitchell. Credit: AFL Photos

Hawthorn are desperate to add class to their midfield next season. Jai Newcombe has emerged a potential A-grader but is seen as a more inside bull, while Will Day continues to battle a lingering foot injury.

Mitchell was coy when pressed about Merrett on Wednesday morning ahead of his team’s final training session before heading to Adelaide for a semi-final against the Crows.

title: Councils propose $37 levy to combat growing waste problem in Aussie city
text:
The levy would be placed on whitegoods like fridges and washing machines to help cover recycling or repair.

After hard rubbish is collected by councils in Greater Sydney, recycling whitegoods can be a particular challenge. Source: Michael Dahlstrom

When an old washing machine or fridge becomes too worn down to be sold on Facebook Marketplace, the only option for most Aussies is to dump it on the nature strip for the council pickup. But a group of Sydney councils is warning only 57 per cent of the materials in large household appliances are being recycled, and the city is expected to run out of landfill in just five years.

The solution could involve asking manufacturers to pay a levy on each product they produce, a project run by the Southern Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils (SSROC) and the Product Stewardship Centre of Excellence has suggested.

Modelling by the groups found that an average of $37 per appliance would help cover the cost of collection and recycling. To “significantly increase” the chances of the product being repaired and components being recovered, that figure would have to increase to $49.

The levy was proposed during a project on product stewardship funded by the NSW Environment Protection Authority. After its completion, SSROC president John Faker said it shouldn’t be up to councils and the community to take responsibility for collecting and processing old whitegoods.

It’s becoming harder and more costly for whitewoods to be recycled or repaired. Source: Getty

Australia lagging behind Europe in product stewardship

Councils were not established to be expert waste managers, and as products have become increasingly difficult to repair and more technologically complex, they face greater challenges in processing them.

ADVERTISEMENT

Participants in the project were told 360,000 tonnes of large whitegoods entered the Australian market in 2019, translating into 200,000 tonnes of e-waste. Composite materials like wires coated in plastic, heat pumps and ozone-depleting gases in fridges were noted as being particularly challenging to process.

Product Stewardship Centre of Excellence director John Gertsakis said a well-regulated program to ensure more whitegoods were recycled or repaired was “well overdue” in Australia. He noted that manufacturers in the European Union are already required to fund product stewardship schemes.

During the talks, interviews were conducted with manufacturers, and they generally supported a scheme to improve stewardship as long as industry was involved in its design.
